conclusion: Analyze the motion of blocks considering elastic collision and frictional forces.
Two blocks, P and Q, on an inclined plane with angle θ. Block P has mass m and moves upward with initial velocity v0. Block Q has mass 4m and is initially at rest at point A.
Block P has mass m and initial velocity v0 along the inclined plane. Block Q has mass 4m and is initially at rest.
The collision between P and Q is elastic, meaning kinetic energy is conserved.
Using elastic collision formula, v_{P_1} = -3/5 v0 and v_{Q_1} = 6/5 v0.
The coefficient of kinetic friction is tan θ.
The force of friction on Q is F_{fQ} = m_{Q} g tan θ.
Energy lost by Q due to friction is ΔE_{Q} = 1/2 m_{Q} (v_{Q_1}^2 - v_{Q_2}^2).
Energy loss is equal to work done by friction: ΔE_{Q} = F_{fQ} * d = m_{Q} g tan θ * d.
Solve for d, the distance traveled by Q: d = (v_{Q_1}^2 - v_{Q_2}^2) / (2 g tan θ).
Using equation of motion for Q: v_{Q_2}^2 = v_{Q_1}^2 - 2 g tan θ * d.
Substitute d and solve for v_{Q_2}: v_{Q_2} = sqrt(v_{Q_1}^2 - 2 g tan θ * (v_{Q_1}^2 - v_{Q_2}^2) / (2 g tan θ)).
Simplify to find v_{Q_2}: v_{Q_2} = sqrt(3/5 v0^2) = sqrt(3)/sqrt(5) v0.
Since no friction between P and inclined plane, P's velocity remains unchanged: v_{P_2} = v_{P_1} = -3/5 v0.
Final velocities of P and Q immediately after first collision: v_{P_2} = -3/5 v0, v_{Q_2} = sqrt(3)/sqrt(5) v0.
